message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s job involves frequent kneeling, suggesting that he may have prepatellar bursitis. Bursitis presents with swelling and pain over the patella on flexion of the knee. There is no joint line tenderness, which helps rule out osteoarthritis and septic arthritis. Osgood-Schlatter disease typically presents in adolescents and involves pain at the tibial tubercle, which is not mentioned in the question stem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest prepatellar bursitis, which is inflammation of the bursa located in front of the patella. Septic arthritis would have warm skin and joint line tenderness. Osteoarthritis usually affects weight-bearing joints such as the hips and knees, but it doesn't cause fluctuant edema over the lower part of the patella. Osgood-Schlatter disease occurs in adolescents and causes pain and swelling over the tibial tubercle, not the patella.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient works as a carpet installer, which may lead to repetitive trauma to his knee. The fluctuant edema over the lower part of the patella suggests prepatellar bursitis. Septic arthritis would present with warm and erythematous skin over the site of pain, along with fever and systemic symptoms. Osteoarthritis is usually a chronic condition and does not present with acute swelling, while Osgood-Schlatter disease typically occurs in young, active adolescents and presents with pain below the knee.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest prepatellar bursitis, especially since the patient works as a carpet installer, which can put pressure on the bursa. The fluctuant edema over the lower part of the patella is a characteristic finding, and there is no joint line tenderness, which rules out osteoarthritis and septic arthritis. Osgood-Schlatter disease is not common in adults.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including swelling and erythema, fluctuant edema, limited range of flexion, and tenderness on palpation of the patella, suggest the most likely diagnosis is prepatellar bursitis. Septic arthritis would have warm skin over the site of pain and joint line tenderness. Osteoarthritis is characterized by joint line tenderness, and Osgood-Schlatter disease is a condition that affects children and adolescents and causes pain and swelling below the knee.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including swelling and erythema over the lower part of the patella, tenderness on palpation of the patella, and limited range of flexion, suggest prepatellar bursitis. Septic arthritis would present with warm skin over the site of pain, joint line tenderness, and more severe pain. Osteoarthritis and Osgood-Schlatter disease are less likely given the patient's history, physical examination findings, and occupation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is a carpet installer and has swelling and erythema over the lower part of the patella, which suggests prepatellar bursitis. There is no warm skin, which would suggest infection, and no joint line tenderness, which would suggest osteoarthritis or meniscal tear. Osgood-Schlatter disease usually occurs in young athletes and affects the tibial tuberosity, not the patella.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prepatellar bursitis is the most likely diagnosis given the patient’s occupation and the location of the swelling and pain. Septic arthritis would present with warmth and fever, which are not present in this case. Osteoarthritis and Osgood-Schlatter disease would not present with fluctuant edema over the lower part of the patella.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of swelling and erythema over the lower part of the patella with a fluctuant edema suggests prepatellar bursitis. Septic arthritis would have warm skin over the site of pain and joint line tenderness. Osteoarthritis usually presents with joint line tenderness and limited range of motion, and Osgood-Schlatter disease typically affects adolescents and presents with pain and tenderness at the tibial tubercle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of fluctuant edema over the lower part of the patella and tenderness on palpation of the patella suggest the most likely diagnosis is prepatellar bursitis. Septic arthritis usually presents with joint line tenderness and warm skin over the affected area. Osteoarthritis may cause limited range of motion but does not present with fluctuant edema. Osgood-Schlatter disease occurs in adolescents and presents with pain and swelling below the knee.
